REYKJAVIK, Iceland (AP) â€” A volcano in southwest Iceland began erupting Wednesday, the countryâ€™s meteorological authorities said â€” just eight months after its last eruption officially ended.

The most disruptive in recent times was the 2010 eruption of the Eyjafjallajokull volcano, which sent clouds of ash and dust into the atmosphere, interrupting air travel for days between Europe and North America because of concerns the ash could damage jet engines. More than 100,000 flights were grounded, stranding millions of passengers.

SAN FRANCISCO (AP) â€” The husband of U.S. Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi pleaded not guilty Wednesday to misdemeanor driving under the influence charges related to a May car crash in Northern California wine country.

If convicted, Pelosi faces up to a minimum of five days in jail and up to five years of probation. He would also be required to complete a drinking driver class and install an ignition interlock device in his vehicle â€” a breathalyzer that requires the driver to blow into it before operating the vehicle, prosecutors said.
Pelosi has been married to the powerful Democratic speaker since 1963. She is traveling in Asia this week.

Candace Cameron Bure went full-on â€™Merica during a July 4 TikTok last month. In the video, Bure sports an ensemble brimming with nods to the American flag, complete with a headband topped with stars.

Bure has not responded to being called out for her foible â€” but if she does, hereâ€™s hoping she doesnâ€™t just respond with a â€œFull Houseâ€ GIF with one of the showâ€™s catchphrases.

BELDEN, Miss (AP) â€” A Mississippi man said his pet cat helped prevent a robbery at his home, and he credits the calico with possibly saving his life.

The Senate on Tuesday passed a bill to expand health care and disability benefits to millions of veterans â€” less than a week after more than two dozen Republicans blocked it and drew outrage from the veteransâ€™ community, comedian Jon Stewart and others.

Many of these vets got sick from exposure to burn pits during the Afghanistan and Iraq Wars.

But last Wednesday, right after the news broke that Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) had struck a deal on a massive tax and climate change package, 25 Republicans unexpectedly blocked the PACT Act despite previously voting to advance it. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) wanted to reduce aid to other countries to help pay for the PACT Act. Toomey wanted to classify funding for the PACT Act as discretionary versus mandatory. Sen. Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.) wanted to shift veterans care into private community care.
All of the amendments failed.
Just before the bill passed, Sen. Jon Tester (D-Mont.), the billâ€™s sponsor, tweeted a video of Stewart hugging him and thanking him outside the Capitol for getting the bill done.
â€œMy man, pots and pans!â€ Stewart shouted at Tester.
â€œYou brought this thing through and you made this happen,â€ he said, walking with his arm around the senator. â€œAnd these guys know that, and they appreciate it.â€

A decade ago, Dan Giusti was the head chef at Noma, which repeatedly has been named the best restaurant in the world. These days, the average person he cooks for is around 4 feet tall and likely missing a few teeth.

In 2016, Giusti left Noma and founded Brigaid, a program that places professional chefs in school kitchens to help cafeteria lunch staff cook up delicious, nourishing meals for kids â€” all within budget.

Six years later, Brigaid is still going strong. In this edition of Voices In Food, Giusti shares in his own words what he loves about cooking for kids, whatâ€™s most challenging, and how heâ€™s taking Brigaidâ€™s mission to populations outside of school cafeterias.

Thereâ€™s a lot thatâ€™s different about cooking for a cafeteria full of elementary schoolers than a table of people who can afford to fly to Copenhagen and spend thousands on a meal, but one thing they have in common is that theyâ€™ll tell you what they think of the food. You donâ€™t pay $250 for an entree to grin and bear it. And with kids, you always know exactly where they stand about something.

The stereotype for what school lunches taste like... isnâ€™t great. The same goes for hospitals, senior centers and prisons. In every single one of these institutions, food plays a hugely important role. Despite this, they arenâ€™t places that traditionally attract top-tier chefs. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m trying to change.

Iâ€™m hoping that when chefs graduate culinary school, they get excited about using their creativity in kitchens that serve these populations. Right now, in addition to public schools across the country, Brigaid has started to work with senior centers in New York and weâ€™re in the process of piloting a program that places a chef in a prison. But it all started with kids.

When it comes to making school lunches, there are a lot of challenges, but the biggest ones are staying within budget (on average, $3.81 per meal), hitting the government nutritional guidelines and making foods kids actually want to eat. Iâ€™ll tell you this: Kids are a heck of a lot more likely to eat fruit when itâ€™s sliced and seasoned than when itâ€™s in the form of a waxy apple not even cut up. But these challenges are part of the fun of getting creative as a chef: â€œYou have $3, a fridge full of fresh ingredients, and a building full of hungry kids. Go!â€

Creating lunches for kids, Iâ€™ve learned that they love pizza from scratch (not so surprising), but they also love broccoli, steamed and cooked in garlic oil. Other cooked vegetables arenâ€™t a crowd-pleasure just yet, but kids crush garlic broccoli.

Just like everyone else, we pivoted the way we worked during the height of the pandemic, but our chefs didnâ€™t stop cooking; Kids still had to eat. We just worked differently, depending on the guidelines different school districts set in place.

The first priority was safety. Unfortunately, many people working in school kitchens werenâ€™t being provided with masks, so getting protective materials was the most pressing priority. Then the focus became: How do we keep these kids fed? In some places, parents could come to the school and pick up packed lunches. In other places, we delivered the lunches to the kidsâ€™ bus stops so the parents didnâ€™t have to drive to the school.

We were also realistic about the type of meals we could make. Before the pandemic, the emphasis was on making everything from scratch. But with other new constraints, we relaxed on that a little. The focus became more about logistics: What was less labor intensive? How could we keep the food hot? Itâ€™s a lesson that applies in the broader sense: When life gets hard, find ways to give yourself a break.

Hereâ€™s something else Iâ€™ve learned: When it comes to changing the way massive institutions like public schools or prisons approach food, the ingredients arenâ€™t whatâ€™s most important. Sure, itâ€™s great to have fresh produce, but what matters most are the people. The thing is, cooking isnâ€™t all that complicated. But without strong relationships, no lasting change is going to happen.

I think sometimes in the food world, the importance of food can be placed over the importance of people. There are some chefs who are really ambitious and they want to focus on the quality of the food and how each carefully crafted entree comes out. Thatâ€™s great and thereâ€™s absolutely nothing wrong with that. But, ultimately, people are whatâ€™s most important â€” and that goes for any system, not just food.

The pandemic has really shaken up the restaurant industry and it will be interesting to see what happens moving forward. I hope the chefs in culinary school right now start thinking about working at places like schools, senior centers and hospitals after they graduate. I think that would be really cool. And it will make you a better chef, too.
Because, again, kids donâ€™t hold anything back. If they donâ€™t like your pasta with homemade Alfredo sauce, youâ€™ll know it. Thereâ€™s no doubt about that.

A multi-candidate Democratic primary in Manhattan has tightened considerably in recent weeks due to gains made by challenger Suraj Patel, according to a poll commissioned by Patelâ€™s campaign in late July.

The survey of Democratic primary voters in New Yorkâ€™s 12th Congressional District found that after providing respondents a one-paragraph description of the three top candidates, Reps. Carolyn Maloney and Jerry Nadler each enjoy 31% support ahead of Patel with 25% support.

â€œWeâ€™ve tapped into both a moment and an argument for change here against two incumbents who are running campaigns that are very, very much backwards-looking at a time when people are looking for hope and light at the end of the tunnel,â€ Patel told HuffPost.
Patelâ€™s advance in his internal polling follows a month of television advertising. He beat Maloney and Nadler to the airwaves with his first ad in late June.

The campaignâ€™s poll, conducted by Whitman Insight Strategies, used live phone and text-to-web questions among 300 likely Democratic primary voters. The margin of error was plus or minus 5.65 percentage points.
There is a major caveat when assessing the significance of Patelâ€™s July poll, however.

In June, Whitman Insight Strategies tested Patelâ€™s support without describing his candidacy, as well as after describing his candidacy. Without a description of his candidacy, Patel registered just 11% support in June.

For the late July survey, the pollster decided to ask respondents about how they planned to vote only after describing Patelâ€™s candidacy. That decision suggests the campaign wanted to highlight only the number that would make Patel look more competitive.

Primaries are often difficult to accurately poll. A race in late August decoupled from statewide intra-party contests could be especially tough to survey. (A federal judge required New York to postpone congressional primaries for about two months so candidates would have enough time to campaign in the new districts.)
In New Yorkâ€™s 12th, polling has been accordingly sparse. Maloney led Nadler by 10 points and Patel had just 4% support in a May survey conducted by Emerson College for PIX11.

The primary in New Yorkâ€™s 12th has been dominated by very public sniping between Nadler and Maloney, both of whom are approaching 30 years in Congress. Nadler has argued that he is more progressive than Maloney, noting his support for the Iran nuclear agreement and opposition to the Iraq War.

Maloney has drawn on her career as a trailblazing female elected official to argue that she is best-equipped to confront the countryâ€™s challenges following the Supreme Court decision overturning a federal right to abortion. She concludes her first TV ad with the words, â€œYou cannot send a man to do a womanâ€™s job.â€

Patel, an East Village resident who identifies as a â€œpragmatic progressive,â€ has proposed a suite of policies designed to combat inflation that he calls â€the abundant society.â€ He also espouses a non-interventionist foreign policy that is closer to Nadlerâ€™s than Maloneyâ€™s in orientation, and has attacked Maloney for previously amplifying skepticism of childhood vaccination regimens.

Patelâ€™s main focus, however, has been in appealing to voters interested in a new generation of leadership, especially people living in parts of Manhattan that neither Maloney nor Nadler currently represent.
The election will be a â€œreferendum on their effectiveness contrasted with a message for the future,â€ Patel predicted.
This is Patelâ€™s third consecutive campaign to unseat Maloney, who lives on Manhattanâ€™s Upper East Side.

The contest fundamentally changed in April, however, when New Yorkâ€™s top court struck down New York Democratsâ€™ redistricting lines and ordered the drawing of nonpartisan congressional and state Senate boundaries. The new, court-ordered maps that emerged in May placed Patel, Maloney and Nadler, a resident of Manhattanâ€™s Upper West Side, in the same district.

Rana Abdelhamid, a left-wing Google employee from Astoria, Queens, subsequently withdrew from the race, leaving the newcomer lane to Patel and Ashmi Sheth, a former bank regulator at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Maloney, Nadler and Patel are due to compete in a televised debate at 7 p.m. Tuesday on NY1.
Early voting begins in New Yorkâ€™s congressional primary elections on Aug. 13. Election Day is Aug. 23.
This story has been updated to include additional information about how the July poll was conducted.

We know that big life changes â€• layoffs, health events, a new baby â€• can cause a lot of stress. However, there are also tiny shifts in our lives (and even our days!) that are often overlooked when it comes to anxiety. Maybe you dread lying down in bed for the night, or maybe the morning rush has you stressed out.

These are called â€œmicro-transitions,â€ which experts define as smaller moments where something is ending and another event is starting. These can include little points in your day, like the aforementioned bedtime, or slightly bigger events, like a vacation ending.

â€œWhether itâ€™s called triggers or micro-triggers, we all certainly have things that set us off,â€ said Jeff Temple, a psychologist at the University of Texas Medical Branch, who adds that sometimes even dreading those transitions can be triggering. â€œThereâ€™s anticipatory anxiety, which is anxiety about being anxious, as opposed to actual things to be anxious about.â€
Whether youâ€™ve been officially diagnosed with anxiety or just feel stressed in those moments, there are ways to identify which micro-transitions are toughest for you and strategies for coping.
Here are some micro-transitions to watch out for and what to do to counteract them:
Sunset
Dark thoughts like to show their ugly faces at night, Temple said, so the sun going down or similar evening-related transitions can trigger anxiety.

There are a few theories on why this happens. One study found that sleep disruption can be caused by an inability to control emotionally negative information at night. Some psychologists blame our caveman-esque brains, which used to scan for danger before bed in hunter-gatherer times. Additionally, our brainsâ€™ active â€œnegativity biasâ€ â€• where our minds subconsciously focus on bad news over good news â€• can be at play. At night, we can reminisce on various negative events that occurred during the day.
The End Of A Fun Event
Maybe youâ€™ve spent weeks preparing for your upcoming vacation with family, only to obsess over your last day as the end of your trip is approaching.
Temple said this can be caused by having a great time and not wanting it to end, or conversely, having high expectations and feeling like whatever happened wasnâ€™t as fun as you wanted it to be.
â€œSo therefore, thereâ€™s a sense of dread or let down,â€ he said. These emotions can materialize as anxiety that you wouldnâ€™t have felt otherwise.
â€˜Audienceâ€™ Transitions
Do you change how you are parenting when your partner leaves the room and your mother-in-law walks in? Maybe you are stricter, or more laid-back.

Either way, Dr. Whitney Casares, a private practice pediatrician and founder and CEO of the Modern Mamas Club, said that an â€œaudience changeâ€ can be a micro-transition that causes anxiety. This can also show up as â€œputting on a good faceâ€ at a party when you arenâ€™t up for it, or feeling like you canâ€™t be your true self around certain peers.
Conflicting Obligations

If you have a Zoom call coming up, and you know your kid will be waking from a nap at the same time or that a repair person is about to arrive, you might feel pulled in two directions at once. Or maybe itâ€™s a slightly bigger scenario: Say youâ€™ve committed to a distant relativeâ€™s wedding and you get an invitation in the mail for your friendâ€™s wedding the same weekend.

Dreading this inability to balance obligations or responsibilities can lead to some anxiety around those micro-transitions, Casares explained. Anticipating or worrying about issues that may come up can cause your body to go into fight-or-flight mode.
How To Deal If You Have Anxiety In These Situations
The first step to handling this type of anxiety is identifying the micro-transitions that are triggering to you, which can be easier said than done, Temple explained.

â€œSome of the hardest parts are recognizing your negative thoughts, or your anxious thoughts ... itâ€™s really difficult. Itâ€™s about being â€• I really hate this word â€• mindful and reflective, and paying attention to your body and your thoughts,â€ he said, suggesting people write it down when they perceive an â€œautomatic thoughtâ€ popping up.

These are thoughts that we donâ€™t even notice we are having, like â€œtonightâ€™s going to suck,â€ or â€œIâ€™m not going to be able to sleep tonight because I have to do this tomorrow.â€ Once we can recognize which thoughts are automatic, we can challenge them, Temple said.

â€œThatâ€™s when you need to back up, and sit down and think about what just happened and what was going on, so then you can figure out what you were thinking,â€ he said. When you do this, youâ€™ll start to notice a certain time of day, activity or anything in your environment thatâ€™s causing your anxiety.

Once you know your micro-transition triggers, you can work to prevent them. Then you can approach those transitions in a relaxed state,Temple said. So if, say, the evening is an anxiety-inducing period of time, practicing sitting down and deep breathing as that time begins can help.
You can also try creating a designated worry time to help compartmentalize your thoughts. This may be especially useful if you feel anxiety before sleep.
â€œSpend 10 minutes sometime in the mid-morning, not right before you go to bed, and write down every single thing that you are worried or anxious about. Stay seated for 10 minutes,â€ Temple said.

Later in the day, if something feels worrisome, validate the thought but move it to that worry time. â€œWeâ€™re not saying donâ€™t have that thought, because thatâ€™s impossible ... weâ€™re saying youâ€™re allowed to think that, youâ€™re allowed to be anxious about that, just not right now. So letâ€™s make a note and weâ€™ll worry about that tomorrow during worry time,â€ Temple said.

Finally, know you are not alone in your anxieties, Casares said. For example, in scenario of a Zoom call while your child is napping, â€œyou could fill a colosseum full of parents who might feel this exact same way,â€ she said. By realizing anyone in your situation might be experiencing the same emotions, you give your feelings some permission and some room to breathe.
HINDMAN, Ky. (AP) â€” Damage to critical infrastructure and the arrival of more heavy rains hampered efforts Sunday to help Kentucky residents hit by recent massive flooding, Gov. Andy Beshear said.

On an overcast morning in downtown Hindman, about 200 miles (322 kilometers) southeast of Louisville, a crew cleared debris piled along storefronts. Nearby, a vehicle was perched upside down in Troublesome Creek, now back within its debris-littered banks.

Parts of eastern Kentucky received between 8 and 10 1/2 inches (20-27 centimeters) over 48 hours. About 13,000 utility customers in Kentucky remained without power Sunday, poweroutage.us reported.
President Joe Biden declared a federal disaster to direct relief money to more than a dozen Kentucky counties.

Last weekâ€™s flooding extended to West Virginia, where Gov. Jim Justice declared a state of emergency for six southern counties, and to Virginia, where Gov. Glenn Youngkin also made an emergency declaration that enabled officials to mobilize resources across the flooded southwest portion of the state.

OLATHE, Kan. (AP) â€” A rare Democrat in a deeply Republican state, U.S. Rep. Sharice Davids of Kansas is one of the most vulnerable incumbents seeking reelection this year. In the final months of her congressional campaign, she is focusing on Republicansâ€™ strict opposition to abortion rights.

An online ad she released last week highlights how Amanda Adkins, the Republican favored to emerge from Tuesdayâ€™s primary for a rematch with David in November, opposed abortion without exceptions. The ad points to Adkinsâ€™ support of an amendment to the Kansas Constitution on the ballot Tuesday that would make clear there is no right to abortion in the states.

â€œThere were a lot of people who would not have known that I have an opponent who is extreme on this issue,â€ Davids, who beat Adkins in 2020, said in an interview. â€œItâ€™s not hypothetical anymore.â€

Thatâ€™s a sign of how the Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in June to repeal a womanâ€™s federal constitutional right to abortion has scrambled the political dynamics heading into the fall elections, when control of Congress is at stake. A half-dozen of the most vulnerable House members â€” all of them women, all representing swaths of suburban voters â€” see the issue as one that could help them win in an otherwise difficult political climate.

In addition to Davids, these incumbents include Reps. Angie Craig of Minnesota, Cindy Axne of Iowa, Elissa Slotkin of Michigan, Abigail Spanberger and Elaine Luria of Virginia, and Susan Wilds of Pennsylvania. They all face Republican opponents who support the high courtâ€™s abortion ruling. Some are contending with rivals who back efforts to ban abortion in all circumstances, including when the motherâ€™s life is at risk.

â€œIn a close, toss-up election, which I think all of these are, it can make a difference,â€ said national pollster Christine Matthews, a self-described moderate who has worked for Republicans. â€œItâ€™s not going to be what drives everyone to make a vote choice, but it will drive some people to make a vote choice.â€

Twenty-two percent of U.S. adults named abortion or womenâ€™s rights in an open-ended question as one of up to five problems they want the government to address in the next year, according to an Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research poll conducted in June. That has more than doubled since December.

Since the Supreme Court decision, as state governments have moved to act on abortion rights, AP-NORC polling has found a majority of people in the United States saying they want Congress to pass legislation guaranteeing access to legal abortion nationwide.
Overwhelming majorities also think states should allow abortion in specific cases, including if the health of the pregnant woman is endangered or if the pregnancy is the result of rape or incest.

Like those questioned overall, a majority of suburbanites think abortion should be legal in most or all cases, according to AP-NORC polling. Suburbanites also were slightly more likely than city residents and significantly more likely than people living in rural areas to say abortion or womenâ€™s rights are among the top issues for the government to address, according to the AP-NORC poll from June.

Thatâ€™s particularly important in districts such as Axneâ€™s in Iowa, which includes Des Moinesâ€™ teeming suburbs. Dallas County, west of Des Moines, has been one of the countryâ€™s fastest-growing counties since 2000, with the cornfields from decades ago now covered in new homes, schools and commercial developments.

In an interview, Axne was adamant that she would make abortion a central theme of her campaign. Axneâ€™s GOP opponent is state Rep. Zach Nunn, who indicated in a primary debate that he opposes abortion without exceptions.

â€œI canâ€™t even believe I have to say this. I have an opponent who would let a woman die to bear a child,â€ Axne said. â€œThis is crap we donâ€™t see in this country. This is the stuff we talk about in other countries and women not having rights.â€
In Michigan, Rep. Elissa Slotkin faces state Sen. Tom Barrett, who supports only an exception to save a womanâ€™s life.
â€œThatâ€™s more extreme than the 1931 law thatâ€™s on our books,â€ Slotkin said in an interview. â€œSo I think that thatâ€™s an important contrast to make.â€
The Adkins, Barrett and Nunn campaigns did not reply to telephone, email and text messages seeking comment for this story.

In Virginia, Yesli Vega, the Republican challenging Spanberger in a district that spans the suburbs of Washington, D.C., and Richmond, has not dismissed the debunked theory that pregnancy is unlikely in cases of rape. Some Republicans warn that Democrats risk overplaying their hand.

NEW YORK (AP) â€” Officials in New York City declared a public health emergency due to the spread of the monkeypox virus Saturday, calling the city â€œthe epicenterâ€ of the outbreak.

The announcement Saturday by Mayor Eric Adams and health Commissioner Ashwin Vasan said as many as 150,000 city residents could be at risk of infection. The declaration will allow officials to issue emergency orders under the city health code and amend code provisions to implement measures to help slow the spread.
In the last two days, New York Gov. Kathy Hochul declared a state disaster emergency declaration and the state health department called monkeypox an â€œimminent threat to public health.â€
New York had recorded 1,345 cases as of Friday, according to data compiled by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. California had the second-most, with 799.

â€œWe will continue to work with our federal partners to secure more doses as soon as they become available,â€ Adams and Vasan said in the statement. â€œThis outbreak must be met with urgency, action, and resources, both nationally and globally, and this declaration of a public health emergency reflects the seriousness of the moment.â€
The World Health Organization declared monkeypox a global health emergency on July 23 and San Franciscoâ€™s mayor on Thursday announced a state of emergency over the growing number of cases.

The once-rare disease has been established in parts of central and west Africa for decades but was not known to spark large outbreaks beyond the continent or to spread widely among people until May, when authorities detected dozens of epidemics in Europe, North America and elsewhere.

To date, there have been more than 22,000 monkeypox cases reported in nearly 80 countries since May, with about 75 suspected deaths in Africa, mostly in Nigeria and Congo. On Friday, Brazil and Spain reported deaths linked to monkeypox, the first reported outside Africa. Spain reported a second monkeypox death Saturday.

The virus spreads through prolonged and close skin-to-skin contact as well as sharing bedding, towels and clothing. In Europe and North America, it has spread primarily among men who have sex with men, though health officials emphasize that the virus can infect anyone.
The type of monkeypox virus identified in this outbreak is rarely fatal, and people usually recover within weeks. But the lesions and blisters caused by the virus are painful.
Debris from a colossal Chinese rocket made an uncontrolled reentry into the atmosphere over the Indian Ocean on Saturday.
U.S. Space Command announced that the rocket â€” Chinaâ€™s Long March 5B â€” reentered over the ocean around 12:45 p.m. EDT.
The 23-ton rocket had launched from Chinaâ€™s Hainan Island on July 24 to carry a new module to Chinaâ€™s Tiangong space station, a station that remains under construction, Space.com reported.
The module made it to the space station while the booster rocket made an uncontrolled reentry, the third such time a Chinese rocket stage has uncontrollably descended to Earth, CBS News noted.
The Aerospace Corporationâ€™s Center for Orbital and Reentry Debris Studies expected about 5 to 9 metric tons of the rocket stage would â€œsurvive reentry and reach the Earthâ€™s surface.â€
Chinaâ€™s Manned Space Agency claimed in a Weibo social media post that most of the rocket was destroyed on its trip to Earth.
Social media users captured the rocket apparently descending in the night sky over Kuching, the capital of Malaysiaâ€™s Sarawak state.
Video appears to show the debris flashing and burning as it makes its way toward land.

Astrophysicist Jonathan McDowell, who works at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, wrote on Twitter that the video implies debris was high in the atmosphere and â€œany debrisâ€ would land â€œnear Sibu, Bintulu or even Brunei.â€
He also wrote that it was â€œunlikely but not impossibleâ€ that some debris could hit a population center.
NASA Administrator Bill Nelson, in a tweet on Saturday, wrote that China â€œdid not shareâ€ info on where the debris landed on Earth.

â€œAll spacefaring nations should follow established best practices, and do their part to share this type of information in advance to allow ... reliable predictions of potential debris impact risk, especially for heavy-lift vehicles, like the Long March 5B, which carry a significant risk of loss of life and property,â€ Nelson wrote.
â€œDoing so is critical to the responsible use of space and to ensure the safety of people here on Earth,â€ he continued.
NASA has previously been critical of China for the uncontrolled falls to Earth of its Long March 5B rocket debris.
Nelson said China was â€œfailing to meet responsible standardsâ€ after a piece of its rocket reentered the atmosphere over the Maldives before mostly burning up in May 2021.

The FBI arrested James W. Clark of Falmouth, Massachusetts, on Friday for allegedly threatening to explode a bomb in the â€œpersonal spaceâ€ of Arizona Secretary of State Katie Hobbs if the Democrat did not resign in the weeks after the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection at the Capitol, according to NBC Boston.

â€œAll of us here today do not want to see our election victory stolen by emboldened radical-left Democrats, which is what theyâ€™re doing,â€ said Trump in his Jan. 6 speech before the Capitol riots, according to NPR. â€œAnd stolen by the fake news media. Thatâ€™s what theyâ€™ve done and what theyâ€™re doing. We will never give up, we will never concede.â€

â€œThe FBI takes all threat-to-life matters very seriously,â€ said Chris Ormerod, the acting special agent in charge of the Phoenix field office. â€œWhile this arrest demonstrates the FBIâ€™s commitment to hold accountable anyone who tries to intimidate a public official, it also shows that people cannot threaten others with violent and physical harm without repercussions.â€
Trump lost to then-presidential candidate Joe Biden by more than 10,000 votes in Arizona.

If found guilty of making a bomb threat, Clark faces up to 10 years in prison. According to the three-count indictment, he was also charged with one count of communicating an interstate threat and one count of perpetrating a bomb hoax, each of which carries a sentence of up to five years.
Intelligence agencies and election officials across the country continue to receive similar threats, said Hobbs.
Attorney General Merrick Garland even formed an Election Threats Task Force in June 2021 to more thoroughly investigate such activities.

â€œElection officials across the country are being threatened regularly for doing their jobs,â€ Hobbs said in a statement Friday, according to NBC News. â€œItâ€™s unconscionable and undermines our democracy. This harassment wonâ€™t be tolerated and canâ€™t be normalized. We thank the FBI for their persistence on further investigating this incident.â€

LAS VEGAS (AP) â€” Intense summer thunderstorms that drenched parts of Las Vegas â€” causing water to cascade from casino ceilings and pool on the carpet of a stadium-sized sports betting area â€” were part of a broad regional monsoon pattern that may repeat through the weekend, a National Weather Service official said Friday.

â€œWeâ€™re getting right into the heart of the most active part,â€ said John Adair, a veteran meteorologist at the weather service office near Harry Reid International Airport in Las Vegas. â€œThis is turning out to be a pretty active monsoon season, compared with the last five years or so. Thereâ€™s plenty of more opportunities for thunderstorms to develop.â€
The annual weather pattern has brought a parade of storms across the U.S. Southwest in recent weeks that lead to flooding in normally dry washes, rain measured in inches and rescue operations.

In Arizona, a driver had to be rescued from a vehicle caught in floodwaters in Apache Junction. A youth conservation crew abandoned the red truck they were riding in at Canyon de Chelly National Monument on the Navajo Nation when it got stuck in the mud and water rose around it. Mohave County sheriffâ€™s officials rescued a woman who was clinging to a stop sign earlier this week after her car was swept away.

Parts of the Hualapai Mountains in Mohave County have received up to 6 inches (15.2 centimeters) of rain in recent days, Adair said. The National Weather Service said parts of Arizona can expect 1 (2.5 centimeters) to 2 (5 centimeters) inches of rain per hour before a flood watch expired Saturday morning.

While the rain is welcome in a region gripped by drought, it creates headaches for neighborhoods where wildfires have stripped the land of vegetation, which normally slows and partially absorbs floodwaters.

New Mexico Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham said Thursday the Federal Emergency Management Agency granted a request to include effects of flooding and mudslides in certain counties hit by massive wildfires this year to the stateâ€™s disaster declaration.
In northern Arizona, Flagstaff residents have grown accustomed to constant alerts on cell phones and sirens in neighborhoods warning of imminent flooding.

Bret Henneman estimates he has about 3,500 sandbags around his home just north of Flagstaff where two wildfires burned this spring. His wife was babysitting and had the back door open two weeks ago when heavy rain fell and sent a few inches of rain and mud through the home.
With every flood alert, they now cringe.

â€œWe still need the rains and all that and we really need the monsoons around here,â€ said Henneman, who is staying with family while his house dries out. â€œItâ€™s just that wildfires have changed everything. So, yeah, when it does rain, weâ€™re in fear.â€

Parts of Arizona, including the towns of Heber, Show Low, Bellemont and Prescott, are near or above 200% of normal rainfall so far during the monsoon, which started June 15 and runs through September. The weather pattern is hit-and-miss, though, meaning some places like Payson are far below normal.
â€œThereâ€™s not really a good explanation for why that occurs, but thatâ€™s part of the nature of storms,â€ said Valerie Meola, a meteorologist with the weather service in Flagstaff.

Jacquetta Brown was walking on a trail in Canyon de Chelly near Chinle, Arizona, this week when heavy rain swept through and she spotted the red truck partially submerged. The rain is a blessing for crops that families plant in the canyon and livestock, she said, but the monsoon also comes with a downside.
â€œWe have dirt roads here, and when we canâ€™t cross the wash, we canâ€™t get to work and school,â€ Brown said.

While only 0.3 inch (0.76 centimeters) of rain was registered at the Las Vegas airport late Thursday, more than 1 inch (2.5 centimeters) fell just 1 mile (1.6 kilometers) away at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, Adair said.

Nearby wind gusts peaked at 71 mph (114 kph) and toppled trees. Pea-sized hail fell from lightning-streaked skies in suburban Henderson, where almost 1 inch (2.5 centimeters) of rain fell in some areas.
Police, county and city officials and the weather service said no injuries or widespread damage was reported.

Casino patrons posted videos of water pouring from ceilings at Caesars Palace and Planet Hollywood resorts on the Las Vegas Strip and from behind a huge video display at the downtown Circa hotel-casino sports book. One video showed a man continuing to gamble at a casino slot machine while water fell around him.
â€œA night weâ€™ll never forget,â€ Circa owner Derek Stevens said in a Twitter post.
â€œLast nightâ€™s weather took Vegas by storm and we were no exception,â€ Stevens said Friday. â€œBut the show must go on and Iâ€™m happy to share that repairs are underway.â€
Roped-off sports book seats were expected to reopen during the weekend, he said.

Rapid runoff from sunbaked lots flooded street intersections, prompting vehicles to creep through high water near Las Vegas Boulevard and Main Street. Flood-control channels turned to roiling torrents. Scattered power outages were reported in places including the downtown Fremont Street Experience casino pedestrian mall.

Las Vegas firefighters responded to 330 calls for service and swift-water teams rescued seven people between 9 p.m. and midnight, city spokesman Jace Radke said. Clark County firefighters responded to six water rescue calls, county spokeswoman Stacey Welling said.

Adair said the Las Vegas area usually receives around 4.2 inches (10.7 centimeters) of rain per year, but the official measuring station at the airport has recorded less than 0.7 inch (1.8 centimeters) in 2022.
The surface level at the regionâ€™s drought-stricken water supply â€” the Lake Mead reservoir behind Hoover Dam on the Colorado River â€” has dropped to less than 30%.
While runoff from storms in the Las Vegas area will reach the lake, monsoon moisture is not likely to affect the ongoing regional drought, Adair said.

â€œFor that, we generally rely on the winter season, where we get multiple Pacific storms coming in and covering a wide area with rain and snow,â€ the meteorologist said. â€œThat can make a significant impact on drought.â€
Fonseca reported from Flagstaff, Arizona.

Olivia Troye, a former Department of Homeland Security and counterterrorism adviser to former Vice President Mike Pence, said Friday thereâ€™s a reason she â€œwent very publicâ€ about quitting her job in 2020 â€• and suggested current investigations into the missing Secret Service text messages involve the same person.

Troye appeared on CNN as part of a panel alongside former CIA agent Phil Mudd and government ethics expert Norm Eisen when she made these claims. News anchor Jim Sciutto asked Troye why the missing messages, which are linked to the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection, werenâ€™t actively preserved.

â€œItâ€™s a little surprising,â€ said Troye. â€œI have worked technical migrations in the government, and I find it a little bit confusing that people were not aware that these messages were going to disappear, especially with the amount of planning that goes into these migrations. I can tell you that firsthand having done it.â€

While DHS Inspector General Joseph Cuffariâ€™s office planned to contact all Homeland Security agencies to assist in recovering the missing messages in February 2021, sources told The Washington Post it decided not to collect the phones or review any data later that month.

â€œI came from DHS,â€ Troye told CNN. â€œWhen you work at the senior levels in the Trump administration â€¦ you know exactly where peopleâ€™s loyalties lie. I know [Ken] Cuccinelli and Chad Wolf and all these people and Cuffari very well.â€ (Cuccinelli and Wolf were the acting leaders at DHS at the time.)

â€œThere is a reason that I went very public with my concerns about the Trump administration, rather than going through the traditional whistleblower process, which would have led me through the inspector generalâ€™s office at DHS,â€ Troye said Friday on CNN.
â€œAnd Iâ€™ll just say that. So, thereâ€™s a level of trust there that you understand.â€
As for the missing messages, the texts were seemingly lost when the Secret Service switched devices and migrated to a new internal data system.

A senior forensics analyst in Cuffariâ€™s office had already prepared to collect some of the relevant phones when one of the deputies who â€œreport to Cuffariâ€™s teamâ€ emailed investigators on Feb. 18 and instructed them not to move forward, sources told The Washington Post.

â€œIâ€™ve got to tell you, being a Trump admin person, most of the administration communicated on encrypted signal apps, apps like Signal,â€ said Troye. â€œSo, a lot of the times, these messages were likely disappearing. So ... itâ€™s a little bit suspect.â€
Troye went on to add: â€œYou can either turn in your government phone â€• was there an encrypted app on it? Was it on their personal phone? In any case, it seems these messages are gone either way.â€

Mudd, a CNN counterterrorism analyst, called the handling of the situation â€œbeyond incompetence.â€ Mudd joined the CIA in 1985 as an analyst specializing in the Middle East and South Asia during President Ronald Reaganâ€™s administration.

â€œHow can the inspector general go to Congress now and say that you can trust me to conduct ongoing investigations when there are these gaps of reporting to you? I think the inspector general has to go,â€ Mudd said.

â€œWhat the heck was the chief information officer at DHS doing?â€ Mudd added. â€œIf youâ€™re migrating data, the first question you have for someone who grew up with a manual typewriter is, is that data backed up? Not only because you are supposed to do that, but because the law says you have to do that.â€

Eisen, a CNN legal analyst, went even further in suggesting that the Justice Department is â€œundoubtedlyâ€ considering serious penalties for those potentially involved in the alleged negligence â€” or possible cover-up on behalf of the Trump administration.

â€œHow many coincidences are we going to have involving DHS and the Secret Service and these missing messages on the most crucial period of time that our nation has confronted in decades?â€ Eisen asked.

â€œI mean, it just strains belief,â€ he added. â€œWe donâ€™t want to prejudge, but [the] DOJ is undoubtedly taking a hard look at some of the federal penalties that can include criminal penalties if we find that this was not an accident, that it was not negligence, that was not coincidence after coincidence â€” but something intentional was going on here.â€

The Jan. 6, 2021, text messages of two Department of Homeland Security leaders during Donald Trumpâ€™s final days as president are missing, The Washington Post reported, citing four unnamed sources and email records.

The government phones of Chad Wolf, former acting DHS secretary, and Ken Cuccinelli, an acting deputy secretary, reportedly were â€œresetâ€ when they left the government in January 2021, wiping their texts.
The DHS Office of Inspector General was notified of the missing texts in February, but failed to inform Congress and made no efforts to recover the records, the Post reported.

This is not the first time Joseph Cuffariâ€™s office has been criticized for withholding information from congressional lawmakers. Cuffari reportedly knew that Secret Service agents deleted almost all text messages from Jan. 6, 2021, for months, but did not tell lawmakers until recently.

â€œIt is extremely troubling that the issue of deleted text messages related to the January 6 attack on the Capitol is not limited to the Secret Service, but also includes Chad Wolf and Ken Cuccinelli, who were running DHS at the time,â€ committee Chair Bennie Thompson (R-Miss.) told the Post in a statement.
The missing texts could have helped the panelâ€™s efforts to piece together the events leading up to Jan. 6.

â€œIf the Inspector General had informed Congress, we may have been able to get better records from Senior administration officials regarding one of the most tragic days in our democracyâ€™s history,â€ Thompson continued.

The panel reportedly interviewed Steve Mnuchin, Trumpâ€™s treasury secretary, and Mick Mulvaney, a former White House chief of staff and special envoy to Northern Ireland who resigned following the insurrection.

Nicholas Sandmann lost his defamation lawsuits against several major media companies on Tuesday.

The teenager, who was 16 when a video of him and Native American elder Nathan Phillips went viral in 2019, plans to appeal the ruling after a federal judge struck his cases against The New York Times, ABC News, NBC Universal Media, CBS News, Gannett and Rolling Stone, according to Insider.

The encounter itself occurred at the Indigenous Peopleâ€™s March in Washington, D.C. on Jan. 18, 2019. Footage showed Sandmann and fellow students from Covington Catholic High School in Kentucky, who participated in the anti-abortion March for Life, coming across Phillips and other Native Americans at the Lincoln Memorial.

One video showed Phillips playing a drum as Sandmann stood before him with a smile on his face. Some of the students wore â€œMAGAâ€ hats, with others interrupting the Indigenous meetup by raucously yelling and dancing to the music.
The footage went viral, and many saw Sandmannâ€™s self-assured smile as a mockery of the event.

Phillips claimed in subsequent interviews that Sandmann blocked him from moving. Sandmann claimed in 2020 that he was actually trying to â€œdefuse the situationâ€ by â€œremaining motionless and calm,â€ according to CNN.

While further footage emerged on Jan. 19 that showed a separate group yelled offenses at the Indigenous group before Phillips even approached Sandmann, the initial video unwittingly made the teenager famous â€” with extensive punditry on major news outlets spurring him to sue.

Federal Judge William O. Bertelsmann summarized in court on Tuesday that Sandmannâ€™s arguments regarding any potential defamation were â€œobjectively unverifiable and thus unactionable claims,â€ however.

â€œThe media defendants were covering a matter of great public interest, and they reported Phillipsâ€™s first-person view of what he experienced,â€ said Bertelsmann. â€œThis would put the reader on notice that Phillips was simply giving his perspective on the incident.â€

Bertelsmann, who acknowledged that Sandmannâ€™s case was filed during nationwide racial tension, clarified Tuesday that his ruling was made â€œwith no consideration of the rancorous political debate associated with these cases.â€

Sandmann, who delivered a pre-recorded speech at the Republican National Convention in 2020 and had then-President Donald Trump claim he was â€œsmeared by the media,â€ responded to the ruling with a Twitter thread on Wednesday.

â€œObviously, the ruling yesterday was a disappointment for my family and I,â€ tweeted Sandmann. â€œIâ€™m appealing the decision in the sixth circuit. Hereâ€™s why: Judge Bertelsmann revisited the statements that I â€˜blocked Nathan Phillipsâ€™ and â€˜would not allow him to retreat.â€™â€

â€œHis job was to rule on the legal issue of what those statements were,â€ Sandmann continued. â€œIf they were factual claims, I could proceed and a jury would then decide if they were defamatory. But if they were opinions, it is protected speech that I cannot sue for.â€ Sandmann maintained that the media outletsâ€™ claims were facts, not opinions, and thus grounds for a suit.

As the Alabama Department of Corrections prepared to execute Joe Nathan James Jr. on Thursday night, against the wishes of his victimâ€™s family members, an agency official told a journalist that she would not be allowed to witness the killing because her skirt was too short.

The journalist, AL.comâ€™s Ivana Hrynkiw, had worn the skirt to previous executions â€œwithout incident,â€ she wrote in a statement. Even after pulling the skirt down to her hips to make the hemline fall lower, she was still told it was â€œnot appropriate,â€ she wrote. Determined to do her job, Hrynkiw borrowed waterproof fishermanâ€™s wader pants from a photographer she had never met, stuffing the suspenders under her shirt to keep the pants from falling down.

The Department of Corrections spokesperson determined this was a more professional outfit, but proceeded to take issue with Hrynkiwâ€™s open-toe high-heeled shoes, claiming they were â€œtoo revealing.â€ After changing into tennis shoes she had in her car, Hrynkiw was finally permitted to cover the execution.

â€œThis was an uncomfortable situation, and I felt embarrassed to have my body and my clothes questioned in front of a room of people I mostly had never met,â€ Hrynkiw wrote. I sat down, tried to stop blushing, and did my work. As women often have to do.â€

Another reporter who was present, Lee Hedgepeth, of the local CBS affiliate, confirmed on Thursday that the department told a reporter her skirt was too short to witness the execution, prompting her to borrow pants from a colleague.
The Alabama Department of Corrections did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Media witnesses serve a vital role in bringing a modicum of transparency to executions, which are shrouded in secrecy. Corrections departments typically keep secret the identities of the executioners and the source of the drugs used â€” which are sometimes purchased in cash to avoid a paper trail. The few media witnesses allowed in the room bear witness to state-sponsored killings, alerting the public to unusual delays, breakdowns in protocol and signs of pain â€” although autopsies of individuals who have been executed suggest that even those who appear to have died peacefully may have experienced torturously painful deaths. Observations from media witnesses have been used in federal litigation challenging the constitutionality of execution protocols.

Corrections departments heavily restrict media access to executions, typically allowing only a small number of pre-selected journalists in the room. They are often only let in the room after the individual being killed has been strapped down to the gurney, sometimes with an obstructed view of the killing. Witnessing executions is a traumatic experience, and the journalists who do it describe feeling incredible pressure to accurately capture details while watching someone be killed.
On Thursday, Hrynkiw had to do that difficult work, wearing ill-fitting clothes loaned to her by a stranger, while a government official policed her appearance in front of her colleagues.

Because of Hrynkiw and the other witnesses to Jamesâ€™ execution, we know the killing was delayed by more than three hours and that the Alabama Department of Corrections has refused to explain why. On Friday, after multiple inquiries from reporters, the agency put out a vague statement suggesting there was an issue setting the intravenous lines.

The state killed James by lethal injection as punishment for killing his ex-girlfriend Faith Hall in 1994. Earlier this month, Hallâ€™s daughter and several family members asked Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey (R) to stay the execution. Ivey denied the request and James was pronounced dead at 9:27 p.m. on Thursday.
â€œJustice has been served,â€ Alabama Attorney General Steve Marshall claimed after the killing.

But Hallâ€™s family members, who declined to attend the execution, didnâ€™t see it that way. â€œWe hoped the state wouldnâ€™t take a life simply because a life was taken and we have forgiven Mr. Joe Nathan James Jr. for his atrocities toward our family,â€ they said in a statement.

â€œAt that point, you canâ€™t really do the same kind of show,â€ Thompson said. â€œSo thatâ€™s unfair to watch it just really go down kind of in flames for real because of those restrictions â€¦ Capping it at 50 might not be a bad idea,â€ he said.

â€œ[Michaels] is such a legend that he keeps off those corporate wolves, if you will,â€ Thompson said. â€œThey spend a lot of money on that show every week. Itâ€™s an expensive show, but itâ€™s a one-of-a-kind thing.â€
Michaels started the â€œcap it at 50â€ rumors last December when he told CBS that heâ€™s committed to â€œSNLâ€ through the 50th anniversary.

â€œI have a feeling thatâ€™d be a really good time to leave,â€ Michaels said. â€œBut hereâ€™s the point: I wonâ€™t want the show ever to be bad. I care too deeply about it. Itâ€™s been my lifeâ€™s work. So, Iâ€™m gonna do everything I can to see it carry on and carry on well.â€

UVALDE, Texas (AP) â€” The principal of the Texas school where the nationâ€™s deadliest classroom shooting in a decade happened was reinstated Thursday, three days after she was suspended with pay in the wake of security criticisms leveled by a legislative committee.
Mandy Gutierrez, who Uvalde school district officials suspended with pay Monday as Robb Elementary School principal, was reinstated Thursday in a brief letter from Superintendent Hal Harrell.

The reinstatement came after Gutierrez, in a letter to the committee members, disputed the key findings that a â€œculture of complacencyâ€ had developed at the school that allowed a gunman to enter the school and kill 19 children and two teachers. She also said the lock on the door to the fourth-grade classroom where the May 24 shooting happened worked when a custodian checked it the night before.

Harrell suspended Gutierrez with pay on Monday pending a performance review pertaining to school security. However, in his Thursday letter, Harrell said she would be allowed to return to work immediately â€œand will continue to serve the district in an administrative capacity.â€

The legislative report placed the most fault with local, state and federal law enforcement agencies, which took more than an hour to enter the classroom where the shooter was and kill him as parents outside the school begged officers to do something and dispatchers took 911 calls from inside the school. Surveillance footage of police officers in body armor milling in the hallway while the gunman carried out the massacre led to rage from families of victims, who have demanded accountability.

AUSTIN, Texas â€• A longtime sidekick for conspiracy theorist Alex Jones took the stand Thursday in a trial that will determine how much Jones and his Infowars website will have to pay a pair of Sandy Hook Elementary parents whose child was killed in the 2012 school massacre.

Attorney Kyle Farrar questioned an Infowars show host, Owen Shroyer, whoâ€™s been with the conspiracy outlet since 2016, over the responsibility Infowars had to vet its information before presenting it as fact to an audience of potentially millions of listeners.

Farrar paid particular attention to a 2017 video of Shroyer in which he presented as fact a fake story about the Sandy Hook massacre in Newtown, Connecticut, that was published on the blog ZeroHedge. (U.S. intelligence officials have accused ZeroHedge of publishing Kremlin propaganda.)

The story in question, by an anonymous user named â€œZeroPointNow,â€ portrayed father Neil Heslin as a liar when he recalled holding his dead son Jesseâ€™s body in a separate interview with NBC Newsâ€™ Megyn Kelly.
â€œI lost my son. I buried my son. I held my son with a bullet hole through his head,â€ Heslin told Kelly in the June 2017 segment.

A jury will soon decide how much money Jones and Infowars will have to pay Heslin and Scarlett Lewis for the pain and harassment theyâ€™ve endured because of Jones repeatedly saying the shooting was fake.

Shroyer told viewers in the 2017 Infowarsâ€™ segment that â€œfact checkersâ€ said ZeroHedgeâ€™s story had merit. Yet on the stand Thursday, Shroyer admitted he has no idea who â€œZeroPointNowâ€ is. And the fact-checker he referenced on that episode was Jim Fetzer, author of the book â€œNobody Died at Sandy Hook.â€
â€œYou did zero to determine if the story was accurate, right?â€ asked Farrar.
â€œCorrect,â€ said Shroyer. He later acknowledged, â€œI could have done a better job.â€
â€œYou could have done A job,â€ Farrar shot back. â€œYou could have done something.â€

Shroyerâ€™s testimony Thursday followed two days of questioning of Daria Karpova, an Infowars producer who repeatedly deflected, claimed ignorance and rambled, until at one point District Judge Maya Guerra Gamble interrupted her with a pointed instruction: â€œYou need to focus on the question youâ€™re asked, not just what you feel like saying.â€
In his opening statement Tuesday for the plaintiffs, attorney Mark Bankston laid out the lies Jones and his conspiracy website Infowars spread about the shooting.

â€œJones told his audience that [Barack] Obama staged Sandy Hook â€• and not that Obama ordered the murder of those children but that there were never even children at all,â€ Bankston said. â€œJones said the school was fake, the parents liars, paid actors. The funerals fake, their tears fake.â€Jones already lost his case in September after Gamble rendered a default judgment against Jones for failing to provide court-ordered documents related to the case.Bankston asked a jury Tuesday to award Heslin and Lewis $150 million in damages.Jones was repeatedly in and out of the courtroom Thursday, flanked by four private bodyguards.Jones previously told the court he would be unable to attend parts of the trial because of a medical condition, yet Farrar noted heâ€™s been on the air constantly throughout the week, complaining about the trial and urging viewers to buy more supplements. Jones smoked cigarettes outside of the courthouse during the breaks.Gamble also warned both Jones and Shroyer on Thursday that they are not to discuss the case outside of the courtroom after they went on Infowars to talk about the trial.Attorney Andino Reynal, who is representing Jones, was seen giving a middle finger to Bankston at the end of court Wednesday. He apologized to the court on Thursday but was reprimanded again later that day for claiming he didnâ€™t know his clients couldnâ€™t discuss the case outside the court.â€œBecause youâ€™re just a brand new lawyer, right?â€ Gamble shot back. â€œEnough with the â€˜Aw shucks, I donâ€™t know the rules of the court.â€™â€
For those who havenâ€™t listened to the leak (or been hunted down by the Beyhive), â€œRenaissance,â€ the new and highly anticipated seventh solo studio album from BeyoncÃ©, arrives on Friday.
